content:
I would like to do a live meeting where I walk through the Polonius design, as we discussed a bit earlier. The idea is to record it and use it as a kind of "introduction to polonius analysis". I am looking for some "interlocutors" to ask questions about things that are confusing. =)

@lqd, perhaps you would be available for something like that? Also, @Aaron Weiss, you might be interested?

I could imagine doing this on Thursday or Friday.
Thursday and Friday would both work great for me. :blush:
could be interesting :)
(even though, with work, chat availability is a bit limited)
yeah that's a challenge
great idea :)
more or less I know about Polonius but I'm not sure about the very late changes
so would be a great way to catch up again
maybe Friday at .. 12:00 UTC-05:00?
I'm flexible-ish, could also do e.g. 11:00 or 13:00 (or even some other times)
friday won't work for me because I'm flying to Berlin
anyway, I guess I can watch the video later
I could do Thursday, say 14:00 UTC-05:00?
I imagine that works for @Aaron Weiss too
that works for me
@nikomatsakis what level would be expected for people joining?
I mentioned it to a few people who are interested in the compiler in general
I don't know :) I'm experimenting with this format -- I guess any level is fine
probably having beginners is good because thy will help ensure I explain things well
In theory this is still happening, but I've got about 40 minutes to prepare =) (I was supposed to do this yesterday but something else came up)

Nicholas Matsakis is inviting you to a scheduled Zoom meeting.

Topic: Polonius Walkthrough
Time: Jan 31, 2019 2:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

Join Zoom Meeting
https://zoom.us/j/281011986

One tap mobile
+16699006833,,281011986# US (San Jose)
+19294362866,,281011986# US

Dial by your location
+1 669 900 6833 US (San Jose)
+1 929 436 2866 US
Meeting ID: 281 011 986
Find your local number: https://zoom.us/u/anRqzWn04
Unless I call it off ;)

OK, so, @Aaron Weiss, @Santiago Pastorino, I'm thinking about calling this off until after the all hands. In particular, I feel like I need a bit more time to prep, and also — in retrospect — it might be nice to advertise more broadly.
alright, after all hands then :)
Yeah I think I need more than an hour to remember the key examples :)
Or at least to prep to explain them
(FYI, I've created a DropBox paper document)
the example Matthew pointed out last time we talked about an alternative analysis would probably be interesting
(my plan is for that to be the 'template' for a more live walkthrough)
I'll try to be on the lookout for it in a couple of weeks, then. I do rather look forward to it.
this plan/progressions looks nice

OK, so, @Aaron Weiss, @Santiago Pastorino, I'm thinking about calling this off until after the all hands. In particular, I feel like I need a bit more time to prep, and also — in retrospect — it might be nice to advertise more broadly.

@nikomatsakis makes sense!!!

(I was planning on telling @Aaron Weiss that I liked their Oxide work — and that there's also a bunch of us who are huge fans of Amal's work / group — so I'll just write it here instead of before the polonius walkthrough ;)
@nikomatsakis will the zoom meeting be recorded? the meeting time is kind of late in my location(3:00am)
@csmoe yes
but not sure when I will reschedule for
PS, @Aaron Weiss, @Santiago Pastorino, @Zarenor, @csmoe, @Jake Goulding -- I am discussing this idea of the polonius walk through over in #t-compiler/wg-polonius

(I was planning on telling @Aaron Weiss that I liked their Oxide work — and that there's also a bunch of us who are huge fans of Amal's work / group — so I'll just write it here instead of before the polonius walkthrough ;)

@lqd aaa, sorry, I didn't see this before. Thank you! :blush:
